content.description: A right-to-left traverse that gets harder with each subsequent move and then a mantly top-out. Great to do on its own or to link with other problems in the area.
content.location: This starts at the far right side of the Dead Man's Boulder. Match on the corner with a high heel to start. Move along the shelf with juggy handholds and small feet/a high heel. Use the ridgy arete to work up and over the lip for the topout.Easier Variation (V3): Head up over the lip on the good riges before the book corner. This skips the crux moves at the end of the traverse and makes for a slightly easier topout.

content.description: Seeking FA... This is the route straight up through the central overhanging section of the Dead Man's Boulder. The bottom is long moves on slightly positive side-pulls and crimps. The topout seems hard and sketchy but has lots of potential. It probably requires more cleaning up top to be completed.
content.protection: whatever gear and people you can muster, use 'em all
content.location: Start the same as Tripping Billies. Traverse left and then head straight up overhang and then over the lip.

content.description: This is a good first warm-up of the day. It's the top part of "Gravedigger"
content.location: Stand on the ground boulder and match the good corner block. Find two to three good crimps and positive feet and top it out.

content.description: Dead Man's Boulder - Overhanging problem with dynamic moves with several dynos possible depending on your beta. There is a 2x4 to help expand the landing zone, and best to have a spotter
content.protection: at least 1 pad, at least 1 spotter
content.location: Stand-start matched on the big undercling crack. Pull left and under the shelf to the crystal. Use tension/fancy feet or dyno to the obvious sharp jug. Use toe-hooks and/or heel-hooks to grab holds on the lip and then bump a left up to the decent high ridge. Commit to a high foot and mantle up for topout.Photo doesn't show the topout because of the steep ground, but should give you a general idea. Add a sit-start before the undercling match to make it harder.

content.description: Start options (from easiest to hardest - all sit):  1)Reach out and up left to edge around arete and right to sharp edge above the ledge 2)Right hand on the ledge, left on same hold as above 3)Both hands on ledge  For all 3, left heel around the arete, right foot on whatever positive surface you can find. If using #3 start, get into position of 1 or 2, then pull up to right hand on the good sloper on the arete and then wrestle your way over the top. Topout is a bit trickier than it looks.
content.location: Walk about 100 feet right of Dead Man's Boulder at the same topo level. Look for two boulders leaning against each other; this is the left of those.

content.description: Dead Man's Boulder: It requires a funky start and some fancy footwork, but there are positive holds throughout. Very fun problem that may require some thinking about the beta.
content.location: This starts directly below the corner to the right of Tripping Billies. Sit-start very low with both feet way out right, one slightly above the other, with your body just about horizontal. Pull up and get your left hip on the slopy ridge for support. Get a right hand in the crack and keep it locked off to move your feet under you and out left. Switch the hands to underclings in the crack and then get a left on the blocky arete over the lip. Mantly topout same as the end of Ants Marching. Variation (V2): Stand-start with both hands in crack underclings and then top out.

content.description: Slightly cramped and awkward (but less so with good beta) warm-up problem on the far left of the Dead Man's Boulder.
content.location: Start low and in front of the ground boulders on the good low block/arete. Use a high heel to work your way left and slightly up to use the crack as an undercling for both hands. Reach your left hand up and around to the blocky jug on the corner. Use the good crimps to move up and top out.

content.description: A large overhanging boulder is the main attraction with several established problems and more potential. It looks similar to the Dragon's Lair boulder. There are assorted smaller boulders heading south both uphill and downhill from this one. Most of the rock is not crumbly, but there are some obvious thin flakes that are going to come off soon. A lot of the problems on the main boulder are wet and/or icy in winter and early spring, but they do dry out in summer.
